column1: Coughing up blood is the spitting up of blood or bloody mucus from the lungs and throat (respiratory tract).
Coughing up blood is not the same as bleeding from the mouth, throat, or gastrointestinal tract.
Most people do well with treatment to treat the symptoms and the underlying disease.
People with severe hemoptysis may die.

These include: - Blood clot in the lung - Breathing food or other material into the lungs (pulmonary aspiration) - Bronchoscopy with biopsy - Bronchiectasis - Bronchitis - Cancer - Cystic fibrosis - Inflammation of the blood vessels in the lung (vasculitis) - Injury to the arteries of the lungs - Irritation of the throat from violent coughing (small amounts of blood) - Pneumonia or other lung infections - Pulmonary edema - Systemic lupus erythematosus - Tuberculosis - Very thin blood (from blood thinning medications, most often at higher than recommended levels)
Call your doctor any time you cough up blood, even if you do not have any other symptoms.
In an emergency, your health care provider will give you treatments to control your condition.
